DIV1.P: Three Hours after Marriage.
A COMEDY.
Three Hours after Marriage.
A COMEDY, As it is Acted at the Theatre Royal.
LONDON: Printed for BERNARD LINTOT between the Temple Gates, Fleetstreet. 1717.

DIV1.HEAD: Advertisement.
DIV1.P: IT may be necessary to acquaint the Reader, that this Play is printed ex∣actly as it is acted; for, tho' the Players in Compliance with the Taste of the Town, broke it into five Parts in the Re∣presentation; yet, as the Action pauses, and the Stage is left vacant but three times, so it properly consists but of three Acts, like the Spanish Comedies.

I must farther own the Assistance I have receiv'd in this Piece from two of my Friends; who, tho' they will not allow me the Honour of having their Names join'd with mine, cannot deprive me of the Pleasure of making this Acknow∣ledgment.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.L: AUTHORS are judg'd by strange capricious Rules,
The Great Ones are thought mad, the Small Ones Fools;
Yet sure the Best are most severely fated,
For Fools are only laugh'd at, Wits are hated.
Blockheads with Reason Men of Sense abhor;
But Fool 'gainst Fool, is barb'rous civil War.
Why on all Authors then should Criticks fall?
Since some have writ, and shewn no Wit at all.
Condemn a Play of theirs, and they evade it,
Cry, damn not us, but damn the French that made it;
By running Goods, these graceless Owlers gain;
Theirs are the Rules of France, the Plots of Spain:
But Wit, like Wine, from happier Climates brought,
Dash'd by these Rogues, turns English common Draught▪
They pall Moliere's and Lopez sprightly strain,
And teach dull Harlequins to grin in vain.
How shall our Author hope a gentle Fate,
Who dares most impudently—not translate.
It had been civil in these ticklish Times,
To fetch his Fools and Knaves from foreign Climes;
Spaniard and French abuse to the World's End;
But spare old England, lest you hurt a Friend.
If any Fool is by our Satyr bit,
Let him hiss loud, to show you all—he's hit.
Poets make Characters as Salesmen Cloaths,
We take no Measure of your Fops and Beaus;
But here all Sizes and all Shapes ye meet,
And fit your selves—like Chaps in Monmouth-street.
Gallants look here, thisShews a Cap with Ears. Fool's-Cap has an Air—
Goodly and smart,—with Ears of Issachar.
Let no One Manengross it, or confine:
A common Blessing! now 'tis yours, now mine.
But Poets in all Ages, had the Care
To keep this Cap, for such as will, to wear;
Our Author has it now, for ev'ry Wit
Of Course resign'd it to the next that writ:
And thus upon the Stage 'tis fairlyFlings down the Cap, and Exit. thrown,
Let him that takes it, wear it as his own.

DIV1.HEAD: Dramatis Personae.
DIV1.P: Footmen, Servants, &c.
SCENE, A Room in Fossile's House.
TIME, The same which is taken up in the Representation.

DIV1.HEAD: Three Hours after MARRIAGE. A COMEDY.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: WElcome, my Bride, into the Ha∣bitation of thy Husband. The Scruples of the Parson—

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: And the Fatigue of the Ceremony—

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Are at last well over.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: These Blank Licences are wonderful commodious.—The Clergy have a noble Com∣mand, in being Rangers of the Park of Matrimony; produce but a Warrant, and they deliver a Lady into your Possession: but I have no Quarrel with them, since they have put me into so good Hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P:
I now proclaim a solemn Suspension of Arms between Mdic and Diseases. Let Di∣stempers suspend their malignant Influence, and
Powders, Pills, and Potions their Operations. Be this Day sacred to my Love. I had rather hold this Hand of thine, than a Dutchess by the Pulse.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: And I this, than a Hand of Matadores.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Who knows but your Relations may di∣spute my Title to your Person? Come, my Dear, the Seal of the Matrimonial Bond is Consumma∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Alas! what will become of me!

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Why are thy Eyes fix'd on the Ground? why so slow? and why this Trembling?

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Ah! heedless Creature that I was, to quit all my Relations, and trust myself alone in the Hands of a strange Man!

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
Town.
SP.P: Old enough, o' my Conscience. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: You may, you must trust yourself with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Do with me as you please: Yet sure you cannot so soon forget the Office of the Church. Marriage is not to be undertaken wan∣tonly, like Brute Beasts. If you will transgress, the Sin be upon your own Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Great indeed is thy Virtue, and laudable is thy Modesty. Thou art a Virgin, and I a Phi∣losopher: But learn, that no Animal Action, qua∣enus animal, is unbecoming of either of us. But hold! where am I going? Prithee, my Dear, of what Age art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Almost Three and Twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: And I almost at my grand Climacterick. What Occasion have I for a Double-Night at these Years? She may be an Alcmena, but alas! I am no Thunderer. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: You seem somewhat disturb'd; I hope you are well, Mr. Fossile.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: What Business have I in the Bed-chamber, when the Symptoms of Age are upon me? Yet hold, this is the famous Corroborative of Crollius; in this Vial are included Sons and Daughters. Oh, for a Draught of the Aqua Magnanimitatis for a Vehicle! fifty Drops of Liquid Laudanum for her Dose would but just put us upon a Par. Laudanum would settle the present Ataxy of her Animal Spirits, and prevent her being too watchful. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir your Pistachoe-Porridge is ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Now I think of it, my Dear; Venus, which is in the first Degree of Capricorn, does not cul∣minate till Ten; an Hour, if Astrology is not fallible, successful in Generation.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: I am all Obedience, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P:
How shall I reward thee for so much Goodness? Let our Wedding as yet be a Secret in the Family. In the mean time I'll introduce my Niece Phoebe Clinket to your Acquaintance: But alas, the poor Girl has a Procidence of the Pi∣neal Gland, which has occasioned a Rupture in her Understanding. I took her into my House
to regulate my Oeconomy; but instead of Pud∣dings, she makes Pastorals; or when she should be raising Paste, is raising some Ghost in a new Tragedy. In short, my House is haunted by all the underling Players, broken Booksellers, half-voic'd Singing-Masters, and disabled Dancing-Maters in Town. In a former Will I had left her my Estate; but I now resolve that Heirs of my own Begetting shall inherit. Yonder she comes in her usual Occupation. Let us mark her a while.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Clinket, and her Maid bearing a Writing-Desk on her Back. Clinket Writing, her Head∣dress stain'd with Ink, and Pens stuck in her Hair.

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: I had as good carry a Raree-Show about the Street. Oh! how my Back akes!

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: What are the Labours of the Back to those of the Brain? thou Scandal to the Muses. I have now lost a Thought worth a Folio, by thy Impertinence.

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: Have not I got a Crick in my Back al∣ready, that will make me good for nothing, with lifting your great Books?

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Folio's, call them, and not great Books, thou Monster of Impropriety: But have Patience, and I will remember the three Gallery-Tickets I promis'd thee at my New Tragedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: I shall never get my Head-Cloaths Clear-starch'd at this rate.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P:
Thou Destroyer of Learning, thou worse than a Book-worm; thou hast put me beyond
all Patience. Remember how my Lyrick Ode bound about a Tallow-Candle; thy wrapping up Snuff in an Epigram; nay, the unworthy Usage of my Hymn to Apollo, filthy Creature! Read me the last Lines I writ upon the Dëluge, and take care to pronounce them as I taught you.

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: Swell'd with a Dropsy, sickly Nature lies, And melting in a Diabetes, dies.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Still without Cadence!

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: Swell'd with a Dropsy—

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Hold. I conceive—

DIV2.P: The roaring Seas o'er the tall Woods have broke, And Whales now perch upon the sturdy Oak.
Roaring? Stay. Rumbling, roaring, rustling. no; raging Seas. [Writing.
The raging Seas o'er the tall Woods have broke, Now perch, thou Whale, upon the sturdy Oak.
Sturdy Oak? No; steady, strong, strapping, stiff. Stiff? No, stiff is too short.
What Feast for Fish! Oh too luxurious Treat! When hungry Dolphins feed on Butchers Meat.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Niece, why Niece, Niece! Oh, Melpome∣ne, thou Goddess of Tragedy, suspend thy Influ∣ence for a Moment, and suffer my Niece to give me a rational Answer. This Lady is a Friend of mine; her present Circumstances oblige her to take Sanctuary in my House; treat her with the utmost Civility. Let the Tea-Table be made ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Madam, excuse this Absence of Mind; my animal Spirits had deserted the Avenues of my Senses, and retired to the Recesses of the Brain, to contemplate a beautiful Idea. I could not force the vagrant Creatures back again into their Posts, to move those Parts of the Body that ex∣press Civility.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: A rare Affected Creature this! If I mistake not, Flattery will make her an useful Tool for my Purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Her Jewels, her Strong Box, and all her Things left behind! If her Uncle should discover her Marriage, he may lay an Embargo upon her Goods.—I'll send for them.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a Boy with a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: This is the Ho-ho-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Child, whom dost thou want?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Mistress Townley's Ma-ma-maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: What is your Business?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: A L-l-letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Who sent this Letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: O-o-one.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Give it me, Child. An honest Boy. Give it me, and I'll deliver it my self. A very honest Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: So. [Exit Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: There are now no more Secrets between us. Man and Wife are One.

DIV2.STAGE: Madam, Either I mistake the Encouragement I have had, or I am to be happy to-Night. I hope the same Person will compleat her good Offices: I stand to Articles. The Ring is a fine one; and I shall have the Pleasure of putting it on the first time.
This from your impatient, R. P.
DIV2.P: In the name of Beelzebub, what is this? Encou∣ragement! Happy to-Night! same Person! good Offices! Whom hast thou married, poor Fossile? Couldst thou not divert thyself still with the Spoils of Quarries and Coal-pits, thy Serpents and thy Salamanders, but thou must have a living Mon∣ster too! 'Sdeath! what a Jest shall I be to our Club! Is there no Rope among my Curi∣osities? Shall I turn her out of doors, and proclaim my Infamy; or lock her up, and bear my Misfortunes? Lock her up! Impossible. One may shut up Volatile Spirits, pen up the Air, confine Bears, Lyons and Tygers, nay, keep even your Gold: But a Wanton Wife who can keep?

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Mrs. Clinket's Play is to be read this Morning at the Tea-table: Will you come and Divert yourself, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: No: I want to be Alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: I hope my Company is not Troublesome already. I am as yet a Bride; not a Wife. [Sighs.] What means this sudden Change? [Aside.] Con∣sider, Mr. Fossile, you want your Natural Rest: The Bed would Refresh you. Let me sit by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: My Head akes, and the Bed always makes it worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Is it hereabouts? [Rubs his Temples.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Too sure. [Turns from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Why so Fretful, Mr. Fossile?

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: No; I'll dissemble my Passion, and pump her. [Aside.] Excess of Joy, my Dear, for my good Fortune overcomes me. I am somewhat Vertiginous, I can hardly stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: I hope I was ordain'd for thy Support.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: My Disorder now begins to dissipate: It was only a little Flatulency, occasion'd by some∣thing hard of Digestion. But pray, my Dear, did your Uncle shut your up so close from the Conversation of Mankind?

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Sarsnet and Shock were my only Com∣pany.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
Town.
SP.P: When it was her Interest; but I made no Intimacies with my Chamber-Maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: But was there no Lover offer'd his Ser∣vice to a Lady in Distress?

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P:
Tongue, be upon thy Guard: These Questions must be design'd to trap me. [Aside.
A Woman of my Condition can't well escape Importunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: What was the Name of that disagreeable Fellow, who, you told me, teaz'd you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: His Name? I think he had a thousand Names. In one Letter he was Myrtillo, in ano∣ther Corydon, Alexis, and I don't know what.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sarsnet in Haste to her Mistress: He runs and embraces her with great Earnestness.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Dear Mrs. Sarsnet, how am I obliged to thee for thy Services; thou hast made me happy beyond Expression.—I shall find another Letter upon her. [Aside.

DIV2.STAGE: [He gets his Hand into Sarsnet's Pocket, as searching for a Letter.
[Whenever Sarsnet goes to whisper her Mi∣stress, he gets between them.

SP.SPEAKER: Ptisan.
SP.P: Mrs. Colloquintida complains still of a Dejection of Appetite; she says that the Genevre is too cold for her Stomach.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Give her a Quieting Draught; but let us not interrupt one another. Good Mr. Ptisan, we are upon Business.

DIV2.P: [Fossile gets between Sarsnet and Townley.

SP.SPEAKER: Ptis.
SP.P: The Colonel's Spitting is quite sup∣press'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Give him a Quieting Draught. Come to Morrow, Mr. Ptisan; I can see no body till then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ptis.
SP.P: Lady Varnish finds no Benefit of the Wa∣ters, for the Pimple on the tip of her Nose still continues.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Give her a Quieting Draught.

SP.SPEAKER: Ptis.
SP.P: Mrs. Prudentia's Tympany grows bigger and bigger. What, no Pearl Cordial! must I quiet them all?

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Give them all Quieting Draughts, I say, or Blister them all, as you please. Your Servant Mr. Ptisan.

SP.SPEAKER: Ptis.
SP.P: But then Lady Giddy's Vapours. She calls her Chamber-maids Nymphs; for she fansies herself Diana, and her Husband Acteon.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: I can attend no Patient till to Morrow. Give her a Quieting Draught, I say.

DIV2.STAGE: [Whenever Fossile goes to conduct Ptisan to the Door, Sarsnet and Townley attempt to Whisper; Fossile gets between them, and Ptisan takes that Opportunity of coming back.

SP.SPEAKER: Ptis.
SP.P: Then, Sir, there is Miss Chitty of the Boarding-School has taken in no natural Suste∣nance for this Week, but a Halfpeny-worth of Charcoal, and one of her Mittins.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Sarsnet, do you wait on Mr. Ptisan to the Door. To Morrow let my Patients know I'll visit round. [A Knocking at the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Ptis.
SP.P: Oh, Sir; here is a Servant of the Coun∣tess of Hippokekoana. The Emetick has over∣wrought, and she is in Convulsions.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: This is unfortunate. Then I must go. Mr. Ptisan, my Dear has some Business with me in Private. Retire into my Closet a Moment, and divert your self with the Pictures. There lies your Way, Madam. [To Sarsnet. [Exit Townley at one Door, and Sarsnet at the other. Mr. Ptisan, pray do you run before, and tell them I am just coming. [Exit Ptisan.

All my Distresses come on the Neck of one ano∣ther. Should this Fellow get to my Bride before I have Bedded her, in a Collection of Cuckolds, what a Rarity should I make! What shall I do? I'll lock her up. Lock up my Bride? My Peace and my Honour demand it, and it shall be so. [Locks the Door.] Thomas, Thomas!

I dreamt last Night I was robb'd. The Town is over-run with Rogues. Who knows but the Ras∣cal that sent the Letter may be now in the House? [Aside.] Look up the Chimney, search all the dark Closets, the Coal-hole, the Flower-pots, and forget not the empty But in the Cellar. Keep
a strict Watch at the Door, and let no body in till my Return.
SP.STAGE: [Exit Footman. A Noise at the Closet-Door.]
SP.P: (Within.) Who's there?—I'm lock'd in. Murder! Fire!

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Dear Madam, I beg your Pardon.

DIV2.P: 'Tis well you call'd. I am so apt to lock this Door; an Action meerly mechanical, not spontaneous.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Your Conduct, Mr. Fossile, for this Quarter of an Hour has been somewhat mysteri∣ous. It has suggested to me what I almost blush to name; your locking me up, confirms this Sus∣picion. Pray speak plainly, what has caused this Alteration? [Fossile shews her the Letter. Is this all? [Gives him the Letter back.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: (reads) Either I mistake the Encourage∣ment I have had. What Encouragement?

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: From my Uncle,—if I must be your Interpreter.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Or I am to be happy to Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: To be Married.—If there can be Happiness in that State.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: I hope the same Person.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Parson. Only a Word mis-spell'd.— Here's Jealousy for you!

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Will compleat her good Offices. A She-Parson, I find!

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: He is a Welshman. And the Welsh al∣ways say Her instead of His.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: I stand to Articles.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Of Jointure.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: The Ring is a fine one, and I shall have the Pleasure of putting it on my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Who should put on the Wedding-Ring but the Bridegroom?

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: I beseech thee, pardon thy dear Husband. Love and Jealousy are often Companions, and Excess of both had quite obnubilated the Eyes of my Understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Barbarous Man! I could forgive thee, if thou hadst poison'd my Father, debauch'd my Sister, kill'd my Lap-Dog; but to murder my Reputation!

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Nay, I beseech thee, forgive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: I do: But upon Condition your jealous Fit never returns. To a Jealous Man a Whisper is Evidence, and a Dream Demonstration. A civil Letter makes him thoughtful, an innocent Visit mad. I shall try you, Mr. Fossile; for don't think I'll be deny'd Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Nay, prithee, my Dear; I own I have abused thee. But lest my Marriage, and this simple Story should take Air in the Neigbour∣hood, to Morrow we will retire into the Country together, till the Secret is blown over. I am call'd to a Patient. In less than half an Hour I'll be with you again, my Dear. [Exit Fossile.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P:
Plotwell's Letter had like to have ruin'd me. 'Twas a neglect in me, not to intrust him
with the Secret of my Marriage. A Jealous Bridegroom! Every Poison has its Antidote; as Credulity is the Cause, so it shall be the Cure of his jealousy. To Morrow I must be spirited a∣way into the Country; I'll immediately let Plot∣well know of my Distress: and this little Time with Opportunity, even on his Wedding-Day, shall finish him a compleat Husband. Intrigue assist me! and I'll act a Revenge that might have been worthy the most celebrated Wife in Boccace.

DIV2.P: Hah! Plotwell!, which way got he hither? I must caution him to be upon his Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Madam, I am agreeably surpriz'd to find you here.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Me, Sir? you are certainly mistaken, for I don't remember I ever saw you before.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Madam, I beg your Pardon. How like a Truth sounds a Lye from the Tongue of a fine Woman. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: This, Madam, is Mr. Plotwell; a Gen∣tleman who is so infinitely obliging, as to intro∣duce my Play on the Theatre, by fathering the unworthy Issue of my Muse, at the reading it this Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: I should be proud, Madam, to be a real Father to any of your Productions.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P:
Mighty Just. Ha, ha, ha. You know, Mr. Plotwell, that both a Parrot and a Player can utter human Sounds, but we allow neither
of them to be a Judge of Wit. Yet some of those People have had the Assurance to deny al∣most all my Performances the Privilege of being Acted. Ah! what a Goût de travers rules the Understandings of the Illiterate!

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: There are some, Madam, that nauseate the smell of a Rose.

DIV2.STAGE: [Whenever Plotwell and Townley endea∣vour to talk, she interrupts them.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: If this Piece be not rais'd to the Sub∣lime, let me henceforth be stigmatiz'd as a Rep∣tile in the Dust of Mediocrity. I am persuaded, Sir, your adopted Child will do you no Disho∣nour.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, what is the Subject?

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Oh! beyond every Thing. So adapted for tragical Machines! So proper to excite the Passions! Not in the least encumber'd with Epi∣sodes! The Vray-semblance and the Miraculous are linkt together with such Propriety!

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: But the Subject, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: The Universal Deluge. I chose that of Deucalion and Pyrrha, because neither our Stage nor Actors are hallow'd enough for Sacred Story.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: But, Madam—[To Townleys▪

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: What just occasion for noble Descrip∣tion! These Players are exceeding Dilatory. —In the mean time, Sir, shall I be obliged to you and this Lady for a Rehearsal of a Scene that I have been just touching up with some lively Strokes.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: I dare assure you, Madam, it will be a Pleasure to us both. I'll take this occasion to in∣form you of my present Circumstances.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Imagine: Deucalion and Pyrrha in their Boat. They pass by a Promontory, where stands Prince Haemon a former Lover of Pyrrha's, ready to be swallowed up by the devouring Flood. She presses her Husband to take him into the Boat. Your Part, Sir, is Haemon; the Lady per∣sonates Pyrrha; and I represent Deucalion. To you, Sir. [Gives Plotwell the Manuscript.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: What ho, there Sculler! [reads.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: —Haemon!

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: —Yes, 'tis Haemon!

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Thou seest me now sail'd from my former Lodgings, Beneath a Husband's Ark; yet fain I would reward Thy proffer'd Love. But Haemon, ah, I fear To Morrow's Eve will hide me in the Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Not a Syllable in the Part! Wrong, all wrong!

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Through all the Town, with diligent Enquiries, I sought my Pyrrha—

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Beyond all Patience! the Part, Sir, lies before you; you are never to perplex the Drama with Speeches Extempore.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Madam, 'tis what the top-Players often do.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Though Love denies, Compassion bids me save thee. [Plotwell kisses her.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Fye Mr. Plotwell; this is against all the Decorum of the Stage; I will no more allow the Libertinism of Lip-Embraces than the Barbarity of Killing on the Stage. Your best Tragedians, like the Ladys of Quality in a Visit, never turn beyond the back-part of the Cheek to a Salute, as thus Mr. Plotwell. [Kisses Plotwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: I don't find in Aristole any Precept against Kissing.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Yet I would not stand upon the brink of an Indecorum.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: True, Madam, the finishing Stroke of Love and Revenge should never shock the Eyes of an Audience. But I look upon a Kiss in a Comedy to be upon a Par with a Box on the Ear in Tragedy, which is frequently given and taken by your best Authors.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Mighty just! for a Lady can no more put up a Kiss than a Gentleman a Box on the Ear. Take, my Muse, Sir, into your Protection [gives him her Play] the Players I see are here. Your personating the Author will infallibly introduce my Play on the Stage, and spite of their Prejudice, make the Theatre ring with Applause, and teach even that injudicious Canaille to know their own Interest.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir Tremendous with two Players.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Gentlemen, This Lady who Smiles on my Performances, has permitted me to introduce you and my Tragedy to her Tea-Table.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Gentlemen, you do me Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: Suffer us, Sir, to recommend to your Acquaintance, the famous Sir Tremendous, the greatest Critick of our Age.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw,
SP.P: Sir Tremendous, I rejoice at your Presence; though no Lady that has an Antipathy, so sweats at a Cat, as some Authors at a Critick. Sir Tremen∣dous, Madam, is a Gentleman who can instruct the Town to dislike what has pleased them, and to be pleased with what they disliked.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Alas! what signifies one good Palate when the Taste of the whole Town is viciated. There is not in all this Sodom of Ignorance Ten righteous Criticks, who do not judge things back∣ward.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: I perfectly agree with Sir Tremendous: Your modern Tragedies are such egregious Stuff, they neither move Terror nor Pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, the Pity of the Audience on the First Night, and the Terror of the Author for the Third. Sir Tremendous's Plays indeed have rais'd a sublimer Passion, Astonishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: I perceive here will be a Wit-Combat be∣tween these Beaux-Esprits. Prue, be sure you set down all the Similes.

DIV2.STAGE: Prue retires to the back part of the Stage with Pen and Ink.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: The Subjects of most modern Plays are as ill chosen as—

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: The Patrons of their Dedications.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Their Plots as shallow—

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: As those of bad Poets against new Plays.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Their Episodes as little of a Peice to the main Action, as—

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: A black Gown with a Pink-colour'd Peti∣coat. Mark that Prue. [aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Their Sentiments are so very delicate—

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: That like whipt Syllabub they are lost be∣fore they are tasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Their Diction so low, that—that—

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Why, that their Friends are forced to call it Simplicity.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: Sir, to the Play if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Play.
SP.P: We have a Rehearsal this Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: And then their Thefts are so open—

SP.SPEAKER: Plot.
SP.P: That the very French Taylors can discover them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: O what Felony from the Ancients! What Petty-Larcenry from the Moderns! There is the famous Iphigenia of Racine, he stole his Aga∣memnon from Seneca, who stole it from Euripides, who stole it from Homer, who stole it from-all the Ancients before him. In short there is nothing so execrable as our most taking Tragedys.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: O! but the immortal Shakespear, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: He had no Judgment.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Play.
SP.P: The famous Ben. Johnson!

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Dry.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: The tender Otway!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Incorrect.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Play.
SP.P: Etheridge!

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Meer Chit-chat.

SP.SPEAKER: Ist Play.
SP.P: Dryden!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Nothing but a Knack of Versifying.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Ah! dear Sir Tremendous, there is that Delicatesse in your Sentiments!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Ah Madam! there is that Justness in your Notions!

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: I am so charm'd with your manly Pene∣tration!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: I with your profound Capacity!

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: That I am not able—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: That it is impossible—

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: To conceive—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: To express—

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: With what Delight I embrace—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: With what Pleasure I enter into—

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Your Ideas, most learned Sir Tremendous!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Your Sentiments, most divine Mrs. Clinket.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Play.
SP.P: The Play, for Heaven's Sake, the Play.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: This finish'd Drama is too good or an Age like this.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: The universal Deluge, or the Tragedy of Deucalion and Pyrrha. [reads,

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Mr. Plotwell, I will not be deny'd the Plea∣sure of reading it, you will pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ist Play.
SP.P: The Deluge! the Subject seems to be too recherché

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: A Subject untouch'd either by Ancients or Moderns, in which are Terror and Pity in perfection.

SP.SPEAKER: Ist Play.
SP.P: The Stage will never bear it, can you suppose, Sir, that a Box of Ladies will sit Three Hours to see a rainy Day, and a Sculler in a Storm? Make your best of it, I know it can be nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Play.
SP.P: If you please, Madam, let us hear how it opens.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink. [reads.]
SP.P: The Scene opens, and discovers the Heavens cloudy. A prodigious Shower of Rain, at a distance appears the Top of the Mountain Par∣nassus, all the Fields beneath are over-flowed, there are seen Cattle and Men swimming. The Tops of Steeples rise above the Flood, with Men and Wo∣men perching on their Weather-cocks—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Begging your Pardon, Sir, I believe it can be proved, that Weather-cocks are of a mo∣dern Invention. Besides, if Stones were dissolved, as a late Philosopher hath proved, how could Stee∣ples-stand?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: I don't insist upon Trifles. Strike it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Strike it out! consider what you do. In this they strike at the very Foundation of the Dra∣ma. Don't almost all the Persons of your Second Act start out of Stones that Deucalion and Pyrrha threw behind them? This Cavil is levell'd at the whole System of the Reparation of human Race.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: Then the Shower is absurd.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P:
Why should not this Gentleman rain, as well as other Authors snow and thunder?— [reads.] Enter Deucalion in a sort of Waterman's Ha∣bit, leading his Wife Pyrrha to a Boat—Her first Distress is about her going back to fetch a Casket of Jewels.
Mind, how he imitates your great Authors. The first Speech has all the Fire of Lee.

DIV2.P: Tho' Heav'n wrings all the Sponges of the Sky, And pours down Clouds, at once each Cloud a Sea. Not the Spring-Tides—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: There were no Spring-Tides in the Mediterranean, and consequently Deucalion could not make that Simile.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: A Man of Deucalion's Quality might have travelled beyond the Mediterranean, and so your Objection is answered. Observe, Sir Tremendous, the Tenderness of Otway, in this Answer of Pyrrha. —Why do the Stays Taper my Waste, but for thy circling Arms?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Ah! Anachronisms! Stays are a mo∣dern Habit, and the whole Scene is monstrous, and against the Rules of Tragedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: I submit Sir,—out with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Were the Play mine, you should gash my Flesh, mangle my Face, any thing sooner than scratch my Play.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Blot and insert wherever you please— I submit my self to your Judgment.

DIV2.STAGE: Plotwell rises, and discourses apart with Townley.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Madam, Nonsence and I have been at variance from my Cradle, it sets my Understanding on Edge.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Play.
SP.P: Indeed, Madam, with Submission, and I think I have some Experience of the Stage, this Play will hardly take.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: The worst Lines of it would be sufficient∣ly clapt, if it had been writ by a known Author, or recommended by one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Between you and I Madam, who un∣derstand better things, this Gentleman knows no∣thing of Poetry.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: The Gentleman may be an honest Man, but he is a damn'd Writer, and it neither can take, nor ought to take.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: If you are the Gentleman's Friend, and value his Reputation, advise him to burn it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: What Struggles has an unknown Author to vanquish Prejudice! Suppose this Play acts but Six Nights, his next may play Twenty. Encourage a young Author, I know it will be your Interest.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Play.
SP.P: I would sooner give Five Hundred Pounds than bring some Plays on the Stage; an Au∣dience little considers whether 'tis the Author or the Actor that is hiss'd, our Character suffers.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: Damn our Character—We shall lose Money by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: I'le deposite a Sum my self upon the Suc∣cess of it. Well, since it is to be play'd—I will prevail upon him to strike out some few things.— Take the Play, Sir Tremendous.

DIV2.STAGE: Sir Tremendous reads in a muttering Tone.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Absurd to the last Degree [strikes out.] palpable Nonsense! [strikes out.]

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: What all those Lines! spare those for a La∣dy's Sake, for those indeed, I gave him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: Such Stuff! [strikes out.] abominable! [strikes out.] most execrable!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: This Thought must out.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Play.
SP.P: Madam, with Submission, this Metaphor.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: This whole Speech.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: The Fable!

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: To you I answer—

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: The Characters!

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: To you I answer—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Trem.
SP.P: The Diction!

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: And to you—Ah, hold, hold—I'm butch∣er'd, I'm massacred. For Mercy's Sake! murder, muder! ah! [faints.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Fossile peeping at the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: My House turn'd to a Stage! and my Bride playing her Part too! what will become of me? but I'le know the Bottom of all this. [aside. I am surprised to see so many Patients here so early. What is your Distemper, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: The Cholick, Sir, by a Surfeit of green Tea and damn'd Verses.

SP.SPEAKER: Fssile.
SP.P: Your Pulse is very high, Madam. [to Townley.] You sympathize, I perceive, for yours is somewhat feverish. [to Plotwell.] But I believe I shall be able to put off the Fit for this time. And as for you, Neice, you have got the poetical Itch, and are possess'd with Nine Devils, your Nine Mu∣ses; and thus I commit them and their Works to the Flames. [Takes up a Heap of Papers, and stings them into the Fire.]

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Ah! I am an undone Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Has he burnt any Bank-Bills, or a new Mechlen Head-Dress?

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: My Works! my Works!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Play.
SP.P: Has he destroy'd the Writings of an Estate, or your Billet-doux?

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: A Pindarick Ode! five Similes! and half an Epilogue!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Player.
SP.P: Has he thrown a new Fan, or your Pearl Necklace into the Flames?

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Worse, worse! The tag of the Acts of a new Comedy! a Prologue sent by a Person of Quality! three Copies of recommendatory Verses! and two Greek Mottos!

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Gentlemen, if you please to walk out.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Player.
SP.P: You shall have our positive Answer concerning your Tragedy, Madam, in an hour or two.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Though this Affair looks but ill; yet I I will not be over-rash: What says Libanius? a false Accusation often recoils upon the Accuser; and I have suffer'd already by too great Precipitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Townly.
SP.P: A narrow Escape, Sarsnet! Plotwell's Letter was intercepted and read by my Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarsnet.
SP.P: I tremble every Joint of me. How came you off?

SP.SPEAKER: Townly.
SP.P: Invention flow'd, I Ly'd, he Believ'd. True Wife, true Husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Sarsnet.
SP.P: I have often warn'd you, Madam, against this Superfluity of Gallants; you ought at least to have clear'd all Mortgages upon your Person before you Leas'd it out for Life. Then, besides Plotwell, you are every moment in danger of Ʋnderplot, who attends on Plotwell like his Shadow; he is unlucky enough to stumble upon your Husband, and then I'm sure his Shatterbrains would undo us at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Townly.
SP.P: Thy Wit and Industry Sarsnet must help me out. To day is Mine, to morrow is my Husbands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarsnet.
SP.P: But some speedy Method must be thought of, to prevent your Letters from falling into his Hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Townly.
SP.P: I can put no confidence in my Landlady Mrs. Chambers, since our Quarrel at Parting. So I have given Orders to her Maid to direct all Letters and Messages hither, and I have placed my own trusty Servant Hugh at the Door to receive them— but see, yonder comes my Husband, I'll retire to my Closet. [Exit Townly and Sarsnet.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P:
O Marriage, thou bitterest of Potions, and thou strongest of Astringents! This Plotwell that I found talking with her must certainly be the Person that sent the Letter. But if I have a Bristol Stone put upon me instead of a Diamond, why should I by Experiments spoil its Lustre? She is Handsome, that is certain. Could I but keep her to my self for the Future! Cuckoldom is an acute
Case, it is quickly over; when it takes Place, it ad∣mits of no Remedy but Palliatives.—Be it how it will, while my Marriage is a Secret—

SP.SPEAKER: Within.
SP.P: Bless the noble Doctor Fossile and his honourable Lady. The City Musick are come to Wish him much Joy of his Marriage. [A flourish of Fiddles.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Joy and Marriage, never were two Words so coupled!

SP.SPEAKER: Within.
SP.P: Much Happiness attend the learned Do∣ctor Fossile and his worthy and virtuous Lady. The Drums and Trumpets of his Majesty's Guards are come to Salute him—[A flourish of Drums and Trumpets.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Ah Fossile! wretched Fossile! into what State hast thou brought thy self! thy Disgrace pro∣claim'd by Beat of Drum! new Married men are treated like those bit by a Tarantula, both must have Musick: But where are the Notes that can expell a Wife! Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Fossile in a Footman's Cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: A Special Dog; this Footman of my Wife's! as mercenary as the Porter of a First Minister! why should she place him as a Centinel at my Door? unquestionably, to carry on her intriegues. Why did I Bribe him to Lend me his Livery? to discover those intrigues. And now, O wretched Fossile, thou hast debas'd thyself into the low Character of a Footman. What then? Gods and Demi-gods have assum'd viler shapes: They, to make a Cuckold; I, to prove myself one. Why then should my Meta∣morphosis be more shameful, when my purpose is more honest?

SP.SPEAKER: Footman.
SP.P: Ay, this is her Livery. Friend, give this to your Mistress.

DIV2.STAGE: [Gives a Letter to Fossile and Exit.]

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile
SP.P: [reads.] Madam, You have Jilt∣ed me. What I gave you cost me dear; what you might have given me, would have cost you nothing. You shall use my next Present with more respect. I Presented you a fine Snuff-Box, you gave it to that Coxcomb Underplot, and Underplot gave it to my Wife. Judge of my Surprise.

DIV2.P: A fine circulation of a Snuff-Box! in time I shall have the rarest of my Shells set off with Gold Hinges, to make Presents to all the Fops about Town. My Conchae Veneris; and perhaps, even my Nautilus.
DIV2.STAGE: A Knocking at the Door. Enter an Old Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Woman.
SP.P: Can I speak with your good Mi∣stress? Honest Friend,

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: No, She's busy.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Woman.
SP.P: Madam Wyburn presents her Service and has sent this Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile
SP.P:
[reads.] Being taken up with wait∣ing upon Merchants Ladys this morning, I have sent to acquaint you my dear sweet Mrs. Townley, that the Alderman agrees to
every thing but putting away his Wife, which he says is not Decent at that end of the Town. He desires a Meeting this Evening.

DIV3.HEAD: Postscript.
DIV3.STAGE: He does not like the Grocer's Wife at all.
DIV3.P: Bless me! what a libidinous Age we Live in! neither his own Wife! nor the Grocer's Wife! will People like Nobody's Wife but mine!
DIV3.STAGE: [Knocking at the Door. Enter Footman, gives a Letter and Exit.]
[Enter another Footman, gives a Letter, and Exit.]
DIV3.P: Fossile [reads.] Sincerely Madam, I cannot spare that Summ; especially in Month∣ly payments. My good Friend and Neigh∣bour Pinch, a quiet, sober Man, is content to go a third part, only for Leave to Visit upon Sabbath days.
Well, Frugality is laudable even in Iniquity! Now for this other.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile
SP.P: [reads.] Madam, I can't make you Rich, but I can make you Immortal.
Verses on Mrs. Susanna Townley, in the front Box dress'd in Green.
In You the Beautys of the Spring are seen, Your Cheeks are Roses, and your Dress is Green.
A poor Dog of a Poet! I fear him not.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter a ragged Fellow with a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Footman.
SP.P: My Master is at present under a Cloud—He begs you will deliver this Let∣ter to your Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile
SP.P: [reads.] I am reduced by your Fa∣vours to ask the thing I formerly deny'd; that you would entertain me as a Husband, who can no longer keep you as a Mistress.

DIV3.P:
Why did I part with this Fellow? This was a Proposal indeed, to make both me and him∣self happy at once! He shall have her, and a Twelve-month's Fees into the Bargain. Where shall I find him?—Why was the Mistress of all Mankind unknown to thee alone? Why is Na∣ture so dark in our greatest Concerns? Why are there no external Symptoms of Defloration, nor any Pathognomick of the Loss of Virginity but a big Belly? Why, has not Lewdness it's To∣kens like the Plague? Why must a Man know
Rain by the aking of his Corns, and have no prognostick of what is of infinitely greater Mo∣ment, Cuckoldome? Or if there are any Marks of Chastity, why is the Enquiry allowed only to Jews, and deny'd to Christians? O Town∣ly, Townly! once to me the fragrant Rose; now Aloes, Wormwood and Snake-root! but I must not be seen.
DIV3.STAGE: As Townly and Sarsenet enter, Fossile sneaks off.

SP.SPEAKER: Townly.
SP.P: Sarsenet, we are betray'd. I have discovered my Husband posted at the Door in Hugh's Livery, he has intercepted all my Let∣ters. I immediately writ this, which is the only thing that can bring us off. Run this Moment to Plotwell, get him to copy it, and send it directed to me by his own Servant with the utmost Expedition. He is now at the Chocolate-House in the next Street.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarsenet.
SP.P: I fly Madam; but how will you disengage your self from the Affair with Ʋn∣derplot?

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Leave it to me. Though he wants Sense, he's handsome, and I like the Fellow; and if he is lucky enough to come in my Husband's Absence.—But prithee Sarsenet make haste. [Exit Townly and Sarsenet, upon which Fossile re enters, to him Under-plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: Hearke'e, Friend. I never talk with one of your Coat, but I first tip him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Behold the Lucre of a Pimp! between the Pox abroad, and my Plague at home, I find a Man may never want Fees. [aside.] Your Ho∣nour's Commands, I pray. I long to serve you.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: Ah, Boy! thou hast a rare Mistress for Vails. Come, I know thou art a sly Dog; Can'st thou introduce me to her for a Moment's Conversation?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: What, still impossible?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Still impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: Poh, Pox. But prithee, Friend, by the by; is there any thing in this Report that she is marry'd to the Doctor here?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: I am afraid there is something in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: What a Spirit does a Jealous Hus∣band give to an Intrigue! Pray, is he not a most egregious silly Animal?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Not exceeding wise indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: Rich?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: He has Money.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: That will save the Expence of her Gallants. Old?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Ay, too old, Heaven knows.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: How came it into the Puppy's Head to marry?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: By the Instigation of Satan.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: I'll help the old Fool to an Heir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: No doubt on't. If the Whole Town can do it, he will not want one.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: Come, prithee deal freely with me. Has Plotwell been here since the Wedding?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: He has! too sure: [aside.] He's a dan∣gerous Rival to you; if you have a mind to suc∣ceed, keep a strict Watch upon him, that he may not get admittance before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: Well. Since thou hast shown thy self so much my Friend, I'll let thee into a Secret. Plotwell and I no sooner heard of the Wedding, but we made a Bett of a Hundred Guineas, who should dub the Doctor first. Remember, you go twenty Pieces with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: But here is some Body coming. Away, you are sure of my Interest. [Exit Underplot.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: This was well judg'd. I have a small Territory coveted by two rival Potentates. It is profound Policy to make them watch one the other, and so keep the Balance of Power in my own Hands. Certainly nothing so improves one's Politicks, as to have a Coquet to one's Wife.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter a Footman with a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Footman.
SP.P: This is for your Lady. Deliver it safe into her own Hands. [Exit Footman.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile
SP.P:
reads.] Know, cruel Woman, I have dis∣cover'd the Secret of your Marriage; you shall have all the Plague of a jealous Husband, without the Pleasure of giving him Cause. I have this Morning counterfeited Billets-doux
and Letters from Bawds; nay, I have sent Pimps; some of which, I hope, are fallen in∣to your old Coxcomb's Hands. If you deny me the Pleasure of tipping him a real Cuckold, at least I'll have the Resentment to make him an imaginary one. Know, that this is not the hundredth part of the Revenge that shall be executed upon thee, by R. P

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: [Peeping.] So. The Letter works as I would have it. [aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: How true is that saying of the Philoso∣pher! We only know, that we know nothing. The Eruption of those Horns which seem'd to make so strong a push is now suppress'd. Is the Mystery of all these Letters nothing but the Revenge of a disappointed Lover? The Hand and Seal are just the same with the Welchman's that I intercepted a while ago. Truly, these Welch are a hot re∣vengeful People. My Wife may be Virtuous; she may not. Prevention is the safest Method with Diseases and Intrigues. Women are wan∣ton, Husbands weak, Bawds busy, Opportuni∣ties dangerous, Gallants eager; therefore it be∣hoves honest Men to be watchful. But here comes my Wife, I must hide my self; for should I be detected, she might have a just Cause of complaint for my impertinent Curiosity.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Townley; and to her Sarsnet at the other Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarsnet.
SP.P: Your Orders, Madam, have been ex∣ecuted to a tittle, and I hope with Success.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Extreamly well. Just as we could have wish'd. But I can't forgive that Rascal Hugh. To turn him away would be dangerous. We will rather take the Advantage of the Con∣fidence my Husband has in him. Leave the Husband to me, and do you Discipline the Foot∣man. Such early Curiosity must be crush'd in the bud. Hugh, Hugh, Hugh. [calls aloud, and rings] What is become of the Rogue? [Townley runs in, and drags out Fossile changing his Cloaths with Hugh. Why Sirrah! must one call all Day for you? [Cuffs him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarsnet.
SP.P: A Rogue in Disguise, got in to rob the House! Thieves, Thieves.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Clinket, Prue with the writing Desk, and Servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: St. St—no Noise. Prithee, Dearee, look upon me. See, see, thy own dear Hus∣band. It is I.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: What an unfortunate Woman am I! Could not you pass one Day without an Intrigue? and with a Cookwench too! for you could put on a Livery for no other end. You wicked Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarsnet.
SP.P: His Coldness, Madam, is now no longer a Mystery. Filthy Monster! wer't not thou provided with my Mistress as a Remedy for thy rampant Unchastity?

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Was all your Indifference to me for this! you Brute you. [Weeps.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Nay, Prithee, Dearee, judge not rash∣ly. My Character is establish'd in the World. There lives not a more sober, chast, and virtuous Person than Doctor Fossile.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Then why this Disguise?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Since it must come out; ha, ha, ha, only a frolick on my Wedding Day between Hugh and I. We had a mind to exhibit a little Mum∣mery.

SP.SPEAKER: Clinket.
SP.P: What joy arises in my Soul! to see my Uncle in a Dramatick Character! since your Hu∣mour led you to the Drama, Uncle, why would you not consult a relative Muse in your own Fa∣mily? I have always used you as my Physician; and why should not you use me as your Poet?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Prithee, Dear, leave me a Moment. This is a Scandal to my Gravity. I'll be with you, as my self, immediately.
SP.STAGE: [Exeunt omnes, except Fossile and Hugh. As they are changing Habits, Fossile says,
SP.P: As a mark of my Confidence in thee, I leave thee Guardian of my House while I go my rounds. Let none in but Patients; wan, sickly Fellows, no Person in the least degree of bodily Strength.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugh.
SP.P: Worthy Doctor, You may rely upon my Honour. [Exit Fossile. I have betray'd my Mistress. My Conscience flies in my Face, and I can ease it no way but by betraying my Master.

DIV3.P: This is not the Doctor; but he is dress'd like him, and that shall be my Excuse.
DIV3.STAGE: [He lets Plotwell in, Townley meets him, they Embrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Hugh, Go, wait at the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: This Disguise gives Spirit to my In∣trigue. Certainly I am the first Person that ever enjoy'd a Bride without the scandal of Matri∣mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: I have a different relish, Mr. Plotwell, for now I can't abide you, you are so like my Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Underplot, I defy thee. I have laid the Wager, and now I hold the Stakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Opportunity, Mr. Plotwell, has been the downfall of much Virtue.

DIV3.STAGE: [As he is leading her off, enter Hugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugh.
SP.P: Ah Madam! the Doctor! the Doctor!

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Fear nothing. I'll stand it. I have my Part ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: I promis'd Lady Longfort my Eagle∣stone. The poor Lady is like to miscarry, and 'tis well I thought on't. Hah! who is here! I do not like the Aspect of the Fellow. But I will not be over censorious.

DIV3.STAGE: [They make many bows and cringes in advancing to each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Illustrissime Domine, huc adveni—

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Illustrissime Domine,—non usus sum lo∣quere Latinam—If you cannot speak English, we can have no lingual Conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: I can speak a little Englise. I have great deal heard of de Fame of de great Lumi∣nary of all Arts and Sciences, de illustrious Doctor Fossile. I would make commutation (what do you call it) I would exchange some of my tings for some of his tings.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, what University are you of?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: De famous University of Cracow in Polonia minor. I have cur'd de King of Sweden of de Wound. My Name be Doctor Cornelius Lubomirski.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Your Lubomirskis are a great Family. But what Arcana are you Master of? Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: [Shows a large Snuff-box.] See dere, Sir, dat Box de Snuff.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Snuff-box.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Right. Snuff-box. Dat be de very true Gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: What of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Vat of dat? me make dat Gold my own self, of de Lead of de great Church of Cracow.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: By what Operations?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
Fossile.
SP.P: Have a care what you assert. The Vo∣litilization of Gold is not an obvious Process. It is by great elegance of Speech called, fortitu∣do fortitudinis fortissima.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: I need not acquaint de illustrious Doctor Fossile, dat all de Metals be but unripe Gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Spoken like a Philosopher. And therefore there should be an Act of Parliament against digging of Lead Mines, as against felling young Timber. But inform me, Sir, what might be your menstruum, Snow-water, or May-dew?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Snow-Vater.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Right. Snow is the universal Pickle of Nature for the preservation of her Produc∣tions in the hyemal Season.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P:
If you will go your self, and not trust de Servant, to fetch some of de right Thames Sand dat be below de Bridge, I will
show you de naked Diana in your Study, before I go hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Perhaps you might. I am not at pre∣sent dispos'd for Experiments.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: This Bite wont take to send him out of the Way, I'll change my Subject. [aside.] Do you deal in Longitudes, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: I deal not in impossibilities. I earch only for the grand Elixir.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Vat do you tink of de new Metode of Fluxion?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: I know no other but by Mercury.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Ha, ha. Me mean de Fluxion of de Quantity.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: The greatest Quantity I ever knew, was three Quarts a Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Be dere any secret in the Hydrology, Zoology, Minerology, Hydraulicks, Acausticks, Pneumaticks, Logarithmatechny, dat you do want de Explanation of?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: This is all out of my Way. Do you know of any Hermaphrodites, monstrous Twins, Antidiluvian Shells, Bones, and Vegetables?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Vat tink you of an Antidiluvian Knife, Spoon, and Fork, with the Mark of Tubal Cain in Hebrew, dug out of de Mine of Babylon?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Of what Dimensions, I pray, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: De Spoon be bigger dan de modern Ladle; de Fork, like de great Fire-fork; and de Knife, like de Cleaver.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Bless me! this shows the Stature and Magnitude of those Antidiluvians!

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: To make you convinc'd that I tell not de lie, dey are in de Turkey Ship at Vapping, just going to be dispos'd of. Me would go there vid you, but de Business vil not let me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: An extraordinary Man this! I'll exa∣mine him further. [Aside.] How could your Country lose so great a Man as you?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Dat be de Secret. But because me vil have de fair Correspondence with de illustri∣ous Doctor Fossile, me vil not deny dat Orphe∣us and me had near run de same Fate, for diffe∣rent Reason. I was hunted out of my Coun∣try by de general Insurrection of de Wo∣men.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: How so pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Because me have prepare a certain Liquor which discover whether a Woman be a Virgin or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: A curious Discovery! have you any of it still?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Dere it is, Sir. It be commonly called de Lapis Lydius Virginitatis, or Touch∣stone of Virginity. [Gives him a Vial.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: It has the smell of your common Hart's-horn. But all your Volatile Spirits have a near resemblance.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P:
Right, Sir. De Distillation be made from the Hippomanes of a young Mare. When a deflower'd Virgin take ten Drops, she will
Faint and Sneeze, and de large red Spot will appear upon de Cheek; which me call de spot of Infamy. All de young Bridegroom make de experiment. De Archbishop did make Ob∣ligation to de Nun to take it every ninth Month. And I fly for the hurlyburly it make.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugh.
SP.P: Sir, here is a Patient in a Chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Doctor Lubomirski, let me conduct you into my Study, where we will farther discuss the wonderful Virtues of this Liquor. Tell the Patient I will attend him this In∣stant. [Exeunt Plotwell and Fossile.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Underplot in a Chair like a sick Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugh.
SP.P: The Doctor will wait upon you im∣mediately. [Exit Hugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: I dogg'd Plotwell to this Door in a Doctor's Habit. If he has admittance as a Doctor, why not I as a Patient? Now for a lucky Decision of our Wager! If I can't suc∣ceed myself, I will at least spoil his In∣trigue.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P:
Ah! ah! have you no Place. Ah! where can I repose a little? I was taken suddenly.
Ah! ah! 'tis happy I was near the House of an eminent Physician.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Rest your self upon that Couch.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: If I lay a few Minutes cover'd up warm in a Bed, I believe I might recover.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Underplot in disguise! I'll be his Doctor, and cure him of these Frolicks. [aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: What are your Symptoms, Sir? a ve∣ry tempestuous Pulse, I profess!

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: Violent Head-ach, ah! ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: All this proceeds from the Fumes of the Kitchen, the Stomachick Digester wants repa∣ration for the better Concoction of your Ali∣ment: But, Sir; is you Pain pungitive, tensive, gravitive, or pulsatory?

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: All together, ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Impossible Sir, but I have an eminent Physician now in the House, he shall consult. Doctor Lubomirski, here is a Person in a most violent Cephalalgy, a terrible Case!

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Feel his Pulse. [Plotwell feels it.] You feel it Sir, strong, hard and labouring.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Great Plenitude, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P:
Feel his Belly, Sir; a great Tension and Heat of the Abdomen—A hearty Man, his Muscles are torose; how soon are the strongest
humbled by Diseases! Let us retire, and con∣sult.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarsnet.
SP.P: My Mistress approves your design, bear it out bravely, perhaps I shall have a sud∣den opportunity of conveying you into her Bed∣chamber, counterfeit a fainting Fit, and rely upon me. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: As yet I find I am undiscover'd by Plotwell; neither is his Intrigue in such forward∣ness as mine, though he made a fair push for it before me. [aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: I am entirely for a Glister.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: My Opinion is for de strong Vomit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Bleed him.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Make de Scarrification, give me de Lancet, me will do it myself, and after dat will put de Blister to de Sole of de Feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Your dolor proceeds from a frigid in∣temperies of the Brain, a strong Disease! the Enemy has invaded the very Citadel of your Microcosm, the Magazine of your vital Func∣tions; he has sate down before it; yet there seems to be a good Garrison of vital Spirits, and we don't question to be able to defend it.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Ve will cannonade de Enemy wid Pills, bombard him wid de Bolus, blow him up with Volatiles, fill up de Trenches wid de large Inundation of Apozems, and dislodge him wid de Stink-pot; let de Apothecary bring up de Artillery of Medicine immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: True, we might unload the Stomach by gentle Emeticks, and the Intestines by Clys∣ters stimulative, carminative, and emollient, with strong Hydroticks, quiet the spasms of the Vis∣cera by Paregoricks, draw off the stagnant Blood by deep Scarrifications, and depurate its Faecu∣lencies by Volatiles; after this, let there be nu∣merous Blisters and potential Cauteries—I con∣sult my Patient's ease; I am against much Phy∣sick —he Faints, he is Apoplectick, bleed him this Moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Hoy, de Servant dere, make hast, bring de Pan of hot Coals; or de red hot Iron to make application to de Temples.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugh.
SP.P: Here's the Poker red hot from the Fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Very vell, make de burn dere, ex∣actly dere. [putting the Poker near his Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: Hold, hold, am I to be murder'd? [starts up.] I know you, Plotwell, and was I not oblig'd by Honour and Friendship, I'd ex∣pose you to the Doctor. [aside to Plotwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Very Lunatick, Mad, fetch de Cord to make de tie upon de Leg and de Arm, take off thirty Ounces of Blood, and den plunge him into de cold Bath.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Your Judgment, Doctor▪ Lubomirski, is excellent, I will call my Servants to assist us.

SP.SPEAKER: Underplot.
SP.P: Hearke'e, old Put; I came to take your Advice, and not that French Son of a Whore's Scarrifications; and so plague take you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Doctor Lubomirski, this Vial that you have intrusted in my custody, shall be with Ac∣knowledgement return'd after a few Experiments; I must crave your indulgence, Diseases, you know, Sir, are impertinent, and will tie themselves to no Hours, poor Lady Hyppokekoana!

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Ah Sir! I beg your pardon, if you make visit to de Patient, me will divert myself in your Study till you make return.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: That cannot be, I have a Lady just coming to consult me in a case of Secrecy.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Have you not de Wife? Me will make Conversation wid de Ladies till you come.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: They see no Company in the Morning, they are all in deshabilleè; most learned Doctor Lubomirski, your humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Most illustrious Doctor Fossile, me be, with de profoundest Adoration.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: With the greatest Admiration

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Your most humble

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Most obedient Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: Ah, Monsieur, point de Ceremonie. [Exit Plotwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Hugh. [Enter Hugh.] bring me a Pint of Sack; let your Mistress know I want to see her. Take care that her Orders be obey'd, and that her Trunks and Boxes be immediately brought hither. Sarsnet will give you Directions.

DIV3.STAGE: [Exit Hugh. Fossile sits down on a Couch.
DIV3.P: Ah Fossile! if the Cares of two Hours of a married Life have so reduc'd thee, how long can'st thou hold out! To watch a Wife all Day, and have her wake thee all Night! 'twill never do. The Fatigue of three Feavers, six Small∣poxes, and five Great ones, is nothing to that of one Wife. Now for my Touchstone; I will try it upon her presently. If she bear it to-day— I am afraid she will bear it to-morrow too.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Hugh with a Bottle of Sack, and after him Townley. Hugh gives the Bottle and Glass to Fossile, and exit.
DIV3.P: Sit down by me, my Dear, I was going to re∣fresh my self with a Glass of Canary. You look pale. It will do you good.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Faugh. Wine in the Morning!

DIV3.STAGE: [Fossile Drinks, and fills again, and drops some of the Liquor into the Glass;.
DIV3.P: What is the Meaning of this? Am I to be Poyson'd! [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: You must drink it. Sack is Sacred to Hymen; of it is made the Nuptial Posset.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Don't press me, Mr. Fossile, I nau∣seate it. It smells strangely. There is something in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: An ill Symptom! She can't bear the Smell. [Aside.] Pray, my Dear, oblige me.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: I'm for none of your Slops. I'll fill my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: I must own, I have put some resto∣rative Drops in it, which are excellent. I may drink it safely. [Aside.] [Drinks.] The next Glass I prepare for you.

DIV3.STAGE: [Townley Drinks. Fossile runs behind to Support her; then pores upon her Cheek, and touches it with his Finger.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Your Insolence is insupportable. 'Twas but this Moment you suspected my Virtue; and now my Complexion. Put on your Spe∣ctacles. No Red was ever laid upon these Cheeks. I'll fly thee, and die a Maid, rather than live under the same Roof with Jealousy and Caprice.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: O thou spotless Innocence! I cannot refrain Tears of Joy. Forgive me, and I'll tell thee all. These Drops have been a Secret in our Family for many Years. They are call'd the Touchstone of Virginity. The Males ad∣minister it to the Brides on their Wedding-Day; and by its Virtue have ascertain'd the Honour of the Fossiles from Generation to Generation. There are Family Customs, which it is almost impious to naglect.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Had you married a Person of doubt∣ful Reputation—But me, Mr. Fossile!

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: I did not indeed suspect thee. But my Mother obliged me to this Experiment with her dy∣ing Words—My Wife is chaste: And to preserve her so, 'tis necessary that I have none but chaste Ser∣vants about her. I'll make the Experiment on all my Female Domesticks. [Aside.] I will now, my Dear, in thy Presence, put all my Family to the Trial. Here! bid my Niece, and all the Maid-Servants come before me. [Calling out.

Give Ear, all ye Virgins: We make Proclama∣tion in the Name of the Chaste Diana, being resolv'd to make a Solemn Essay of the Virtue, Virginity, and Chastity of all within our Walls. We therefore Advise, Warn and Precaution all Spinsters, who know themselves Blemish'd, not on any Pretence whatsoever to Taste these our
Drops, which will manifest their Shame to the World by visible Tokens.

SP.SPEAKER: Clinket.
SP.P: I abominate all Kind of Drops. They interrupt the Series of Idea's. But have they any Power over the Virgin's Dreams, Thoughts, and private Meditations?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: No. They do not affect the motus Primo-primi, or Intentions; only Actualities, Niece.

SP.SPEAKER: Clinket.
SP.P: Then give it me. I can drink as freely of it, as of the Waters of Helicon. My Love was always Platonick.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Yet I have known a Platonick Lady lodge at a Midwife's.

SP.SPEAKER: First Woman.
SP.P: I never take Physick.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: That's one. Stand there. My Niece professes her self a Platonick. You are rather a Cartesian.

SP.SPEAKER: Clinket.
SP.P: Ah dear Uncle! How do the Plato∣nicks and Cartesians differ?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: The Platonicks are for Idea's, the Car∣tesians for Matter and Motion.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Mr. Fossile, you are too severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Second Woman.
SP.P: I am not a-dry.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: There's Two. Stand there.

SP.SPEAKER: Prue.
SP.P: My Mistress can Answer for me. She has taken it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: She has. But however stand there, among the Cartesians.

SP.SPEAKER: Third Woman.
SP.P: My Innocence would protect me, though I trod over red-hot Iron. Give me a Brimmer.

DIV3.STAGE: [She takes a Mouthful, and spits it out again.]

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: 'Twas a presumptuous Thing to Gar∣gle with it: But however, Madam, if you please —walk among the Cartesians.

SP.SPEAKER: Clinket.
SP.P: Prue, follow me. I have just found a Rhime for my Pindarick.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: All gone! What no more Ladies here? No more Ladies! [looking to the Audience,] O that I had but a Boarding-School, or a Middle-Gallery!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sarsnet, follow'd by Two Porters bearing a Chest.
DIV3.P: Set down the Things here: There is no Oc∣caion for carrying them up Stairs, since they are to be sent into the Countrey to-Morrow.

What have I done? My Marriage, these con∣founded Whimsies, and Doctor Lubomirski, have made me quite forget poor Lady Hippokekoana. She was in Convulsions, and I am afraid dead by this Time. [Exit Fossile.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarsnet.
SP.P: I have brought you a Present, Madam, make good Use of it. So I leave you together.

DIV3.STAGE: [Townley opens the Chest: Plotwell, who was cover'd with a Gown and Petticoat, gets out.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Never was any Thing so lucky. The Doctor is just this Minute gone to a Patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: I tempt Dangers enough in your Service. I am almost crippled in this Chest-Adventure. Oh my Knees! Prithee, my Dear, lead me to a Bed where I may stretch my self out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sarsnet.
SP.P: Oh Madam! yonder is the Doctor in deep Discourse with Underplot: I fear he has dogg'd me, and betray'd us. They are both coming back together.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: I'll shrink snug into my Shell again.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: That he may directly pop upon you. The Trunk will be the first Place he will examine. Have you no Presence of Mind? You fit for an Intrigue!

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: What shall I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Fear not, you shall be Invisible on this very Spot.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: What do you mean? He's just at the Door. You intend to discover me.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P:
Mistrust me not: You shall walk out before his Face at that very Door, though he
bring in a Hundred Spies, and not one of them shall perceive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell,
SP.P: Don't trifle. Are you Mad? [Knocking at the Door] Nay, now 'tis too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Arm thy self with Flounces, and fortify thy self with Whalebone; enter beneath the Cupolo of this Petticoat.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: The best Security in the World! an Old Fellow has seldom any Thing to do beneath that Circumference.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: No more. But under it immediately.

DIV3.P: Thus Venus, when approaching Foes assail, Shields her Aeneas with a Silken Veil.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: O my Dear, you come opportunely. How do you like my Fancy in this new Pet∣ticoat? There is something in it so odd!

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: You have another in your Chest much odder. I want to see that.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: How jaunty the Flounces!

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Ay, 'tis plain she would lure me from the Chest; there I shall find him.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: The Lace! the Fringe!

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: All this is nothing to the embroi∣der'd Sattin. Prithee, my Dear, give me the Key.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Sure never was any Thing so prettily disposed. Observe but the Air of it: So Degageé! But the Lining is so charming.

DIV3.STAGE: [She walks, to the Door, and Fossile to the Trunk. Plotwell kisses her out of the top of the Petticoat, and then goes off.]
[As Fossile is cautiously opening the Trunk with his Sword drawn, Townley comes up to him.]
DIV3.P: What more of your Frolicks, Mr. Fossile? What Time of the Moon is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: This Underplot is a confounded Vil∣lain, he would make me jealous of an honest civil Gentleman, only for an Opportunity to Cuckold me himself. [Aside.] Come, my Dear, forget all that is past. I know—I have prov'd thee Virtuous.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Fossile with a Vial in his Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: THIS is all we have for the flying Dragon so celebrated by Antiquity. A cheap Purchase! It cost me but Fifteen Gui∣neas. But the Jew made it up in the Butterfly and the Spider.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Two Porters bearing a Mummy.
DIV2.P: Oh! here's my Mummy. Set him down. I am in Haste. Tell Captain Bantam, I'll talk with him at the Coffee-House. [Ex. Porters.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Two Porters bearing an Alligator.
DIV2.P: A most stupendous Animal! set him down.

Poor Lady Hippokekoana's Convulsions! I be∣lieve there is a Fatality in it, that I can never get to her. Who can I trust my House to in my Absence? Were my Wife as Chaste as Lucretia, who knows what an unlucky Minute may bring forth! In Cuckoldom, the Art of Attack is pro∣digiously improved beyond the Art of Defence. So far it is manifest, Underplot has a Design upon
my Honour. For the Ease of my Mind, I will lock up my Wife in this my Musaeum, 'till my Return.
You will find something here, my Dear, to divert your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: I hate the Sight of these strange Creatures; but since I am Mr. Fossile's Wife, I shall endeavour to conquer my Aversion.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Thou may'st safely be here to Day, my Dear; to Morrow thou should'st no more enter this Room than a Pest-house. 'Tis dan∣gerous for Women that are Impregnated. But poor Lady Hippokekoana suffers all this whi.

DIV2.STAGE: [Ex. Fossile with a Key in his Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Since he has lock'd me in, to be even with him, I'll bolt him out.

DIV2.STAGE: [Plotwell, dress'd like a Mummy, comes forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Plot.
SP.P: Thus trav'ling far from his Egyptian Tomb, Thy Antony salutes his Cleopatra.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Thus Cleopatra, in desiring Arms▪ Receives her Antony—But prithee dear pickled Hieroglyphick, who so suddenly could assist thee with this Shape?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotwell.
SP.P: The Play-house can dress Mummies, Bears, Lions, Crocodiles, and all the Monsters of Lybia. My Arms, Madam, are ready to break their Past-board Prison to embrace you.

SP.SPEAKER: Townly.
SP.P: Not so hasty. Stay till the jealous Fool is out of Sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Our ill Stars, and the Devil, have brought him back so often—

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: He can never parry this Blow, nor grow jealous of his Mummy. A Mummy is his intimate Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: And a Man cannot easily be Cuckolded by any Body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Here may'st thou remain the Orna∣ment of his Study, and the Support of his Old Age. Thou shalt divert his Company, and be a Father to his Children. I will bring thee Legs of Pullets, Remnants of Tarts, and Fragments of Disserts. Thou shalt be fed like Bell and the Dragon.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: But Madam; before you entertain me as your Mummy in Ordinary, you ought to be acquainted with my Abilities to discharge that Office. Let me slip off this Habit of Death, you shall find I have some Symptoms of Life.—Thus Jove within the Milk-white Swan compress'd his Leda.

DIV2.STAGE: [Underplot in the Alligator crawls forward, then rises up and embraces her.]

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: Thus Jove within the Serpent's scaly Folds, Twin'd round the Macedonian Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Fear not, Madam. This is my evil Genius Underplot that still haunts me. How the Devil got you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: Why should not the Play-house lend me a Crocodile as well as you a Mummy?

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: How unlucky is this! [Aside.] Nay, I don't know but I may have Twenty Lovers in this Collection. You Snakes, Sharks, Monkeys, and Mantegers, speak, and put in your Claim be∣fore it is too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: Mr. Mummy, your Humble Servant; the Lady is pre-engag'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Pray, Mr. Crocodile, let the Lady make her own Choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: Crocodile as I am, I must be treated with common Humanity. You can't, Madam, disown the Message you sent me.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Well! Ye Pair of Egyptian Lovers, agree this Matter between you, and I will acquit my self like a Person of Honour to you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Madam! If I don't love you above all your Sex, may I be banish'd the Studies of Vir∣tuoso's; and smoak'd like Dutch Beef in a Chimney—

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: If I don't love you more than that Stale Mummy, may I never more be proclaim'd at a Show of Monsters, by the Sound of a Glass-Trumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: May I be sent to 'Pothecary's-Hall, and beat up into Venice-Treacle for the Fleet and the Army, if this Heart—

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: May I be stuff'd with Straw, and gi∣ven to a Mountebank, if this Soul—

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Madam, I am a Human Creature. Taste my Balsamick Kiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: A Lover in Swadling-Clouts! What is his Kiss, to my Embrace?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Look upon me, Madam. See how I am embroider'd with Hieroglyphicks.

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: Consider my beautiful Row of Teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: My Balmy Breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: The strong Joints of my Back.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: My erect Stature.

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: My long Tail.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Such a Contest of Beauty! How shall I decide it?

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: Take me out of my Shell, Madam, and I'll make you a Present of the Kernel.

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: Then I must be upon a Level with him, and be uncrocodil'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Keep both of you your Shapes, and we are in no Fear of a Surprize from the Doctor: If you uncase, his Presence would undo us. Sure never was any Thing so unlucky—I hear his Footsteps, quick to your Posts.

DIV2.STAGE: [Mummy and Crocodile run to their Places.
[Enter Fossile, Dr. Nautilus, and Dr. Possum.]

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: Much Joy to the Learned Dr. Fossile. To have a Mummy, an Alligator, and a Wife, all in one Day, is too great Happiness for Mortal Man!

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: This an Alligator! Alack a Day, Bro∣ther Nautilus, this is a meer Lizard, an Eft, a Shrimp to mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: How improving would it be to the Fe∣male Understanding, if the Closets of the Ladies were Furnish'd, or, as I may say, Ornamented and Embellish'd with preserv'd Butterflies, and beautiful Shells, instead of China Jars, and ab∣surd Indian Pictures.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Now for a Stratagem to bring off my unsuccessful Pair of Gallants.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Ah, Dr. Nautilus, how have I lan∣guish'd for your Feather of the Bird Porphyrion!

SP.SPEAKER: Nautilus.
SP.P: But your Dart of the Mantichora!

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Your Haft of an Antediluvian Trowel, unquestionably the Tool of one of the Babel Ma∣sons!

SP.SPEAKER: Nautilus.
SP.P: What's that to your Fragment of Seth's Pillar?

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: Gentlemen. I affirm I have a greater Curiosity than all of them. I have an entire Leaf of Noah's Journal aboard the Ark, that was hewn out of a Porphyry Pillar in Palmyra.

DIV2.STAGE: [Fossile opens the Case of the Mummy.]

SP.SPEAKER: Nautil.
SP.P: By the Formation of the Muscular Parts of the Visage, I conjecture that this Mum∣my is Male.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: Male, Brother! I am sorry to observe your Ignorance of the Symetry of a Human Bo∣dy. Do but observe the Projection of the Hip; besides, the Bloom upon the Face; 'tis a Female beyond all Contradiction.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Let us have no rash Dispute, Brothers▪ but proceed methodically—Behold the Vanity of Mankind! [pointing to the Mummy.] Some Ptolemy perhaps!—

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: Who by his Pyramid and Pickle thought to secure to himself Death Immortal.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: His Pyramid, alas! is now but a Wain∣scot Case.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: And his Pickle can scarce raise him to the Dignity of a Collar of Brawn.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Pardon me, Dr. Possum: The Musaeum of the Curious is a lasting Monument. And I think it no Degradation to a dead Person of Qua∣lity, to bear the Rank of an Anatomy in the Learned World.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: By your Favour, Dr. Possum, a Collar of Brawn! I affirm, he is better to be taken in∣wardly than a Collar of Brawn.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: An Excellent Medicine! He is hot in the first Degree, and exceeding powerful in some Diseases of Women.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: Right, Dr. Fossile; for your Asphaltion.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: Pice-Asphaltus, by your leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: By your leave, Doctor Possum, I say Asphaltion.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: And I positively say, Pice Asphaltus.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: If you had read Dioscorides or Pliny—

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
