SP.P: I have read Dioscorides. And I do affirm Pice-Alsphaltus.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P:
Be calm, Gentlemen. Both of you handle this Argument with great Learning, Judg∣ment and Perspicuity. For the present, I beseech
you to Concord, and turn your Speculations on my Alligator.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: The Skin is impenetrable even to a Sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: Dr. Possum, I will show you the con∣trary.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: In the mean time I will try the Mum∣my with this Knife, on the Point of which you shall smell the Pitch, and be convinc'd that it is the Pice-Asphaltus.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Hold, Sir: You will not only deface my Mummy, but spoil my Roman Sacrificing Knife.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: I must lure them from this Experi∣ment, or we are discover'd.

DIV2.P: What do I see! Most prodigious! A Star as broad as the Moon in the Day-time!

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: Only a Halo about the Sun, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: Your Suppositions, Doctor, seem to be groundless. Let me make my Observation.

DIV2.STAGE: [Naut. and Possum struggle to look first.

SP.SPEAKER: Townley.
SP.P: Now for your Escape: [To Plotwell and Underplot.

DIV2.STAGE: [They run to the Door, but find it lock'd.]

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: What an unlucky Dog I am!

SP.SPEAKER: Townly.
SP.P: Quick. Back to your Posts. Don't move, and rely upon me. I have still another Artifice.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: I can espy no Celestial Body but the Sun.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: Brother Nautilus, your Eyes are some∣what dim; your Sight is not fit for Astronomical Observations.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile,
SP.P: Is the Focus of the Glass right? Hold Gentlemen, I see it; about the Bigness of Ju∣piter.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: No Phenomenon offers it self to my Speculation.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: Point over yonder Chimney. Di∣rectly South.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: Thitherward, begging your Pardon, Dr. Possum, I affirm to be the North.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: East.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: South.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: North. Alas! What an ignorant Thing is Vanity! I was just making a Reflection on the Ignorance of my Brother Possum, in the Nature of the Crocodile.

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: First, Brother Nautilus, convince your self of the Composition of the Mummy.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: I will insure your Alligator from any Damage. His Skin I affirm once more to be impenetrable.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: I will not deface any Hieroglyphick.

DIV2.STAGE: [Goes to the Mummy with the Knife.]

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: I never oppose a luciferous Experi∣ment. It is the beaten Highway to Truth.

DIV2.STAGE: [Plotwell and Underplot leap from their Places; the Doctors are frighted.]

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: Speak, I conjure thee. Art thou the Ghost of some murder'd Egyptian Monarch?

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P: A rational Question to a Mummy! But this Monster can be no less than the Devil him∣self, for Crocodiles don't walk.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Gentlemen, wonder at Nothing within these Walls; for ever since I was Married, No∣thing has happen'd to me in the common Course of Human Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Clinket.
SP.P: Madam, without a Compliment, you have a fine Imagination. The Masquerade of the Mummy and Crocodile is extreamly just; I would not rob you of the Merit of the Invention, Yet since you make me the Compliment, I shall be proud to take the whole Contrivance of this Mas∣querade upon my self. [To Townley.] Sir be acquainted with my Masqueraders.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P:
Thou Female Imp of Apollo, more mis∣chievous than Circe, who fed Gentlemen of the Army in a Hog's-Stye! What mean you by these
Gambols? This Mummy, this Crocodile?

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Only a little Mummery, Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: What an outragious Conceit is this▪ Had you contented your self with the Metamor∣phosis of Jupiter, our Skill in the Classicks might have prevented our Terror.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: I glory in the Fertility of my Invention the more, that it is beyond the Imagination of a Pagan Deity. Besides, it is form'd upon the Vray-Semblance; for I knew you had a Mummy and a Crocodile to be brought home.

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Dr. Nautilus is an infirm tender Gen∣tleman; I wish the sudden Concussion of his Ani∣mal Spirits may not kindle him into a Fever. I my self, I must confess, have an extreme Palpi∣tation.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Dear Uncle, be pacified. We are both of us the Votaries of our great Master Apollo. To you he has assigned the Art of Healing: Me he has taught to Sing; Why then should we jangle in our Kindred Faculties?

SP.SPEAKER: Fossile.
SP.P: Apollo, for ought I know, may be a very fine Person; but this I am sure of, that the Skill he has given all his Physicians is not suffi∣cient to cure the Madness of his Poets.

SP.SPEAKER: Possum.
SP.P: Hark ye, Brother Fossile! Your Croco∣dile has proved a Human Creature, I wish your Wife may not prove a Crocodile.

SP.SPEAKER: Naut.
SP.P:
Hark ye, Brother Fossile! Your Mummy, as you were saying, seemeth to be hot in the first
Degree, and is powerful in some Diseases of Wo∣men.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: You Diabolical Performers of my Niece's Masquerade, will it please you to follow those Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, you shall see them Dance first.

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: Dance! the Devil! bring me hither a Spit, a Fire-Fork, I'll try whether the Monsters are impenetrable or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Plotw.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, you will not expose us to the Fury of the Mob, since we came here upon so courteous a Design.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Good Courteous Mr. Mummy, without more Ceremony, will it please you to retire to your subterraneous Habitation. And you, Mr. Crocodile, about your Business this Moment, or you shall change your Nile for the next Horse-Pond.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: Spare my Masqueraders.

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: Let it never be said that the Famous Dr. Fossile, so renowned for his Charity to Mon∣sters, should violate the Laws of Hospitality, and turn a poor Alligator naked into the Street.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Deposite your Exuviae then, and assume your Human Shape.

SP.SPEAKER: Underp.
SP.P: For that, I must beg your Excuse. A Gentleman would not chuse to be known in these Frolicks.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Then out of my Doors. Here, Foot∣men, out with him; out, thou Hypocrite, of an Alligator.

DIV2.P: Sir, the Respect I have for Catacombs and Pyra∣mids, will not protect you. [A Noise of Mob within.

SP.SPEAKER: Prue.
SP.P: Sir, Sir, lock your Doors, or else all your Monsters will run Home again to the Indies. Your Crocodile yonder has made his Escape; If he get but to Somerset Water-Gate, he is gone for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Footman.
SP.P: The Herbwoman swore she knew him to be the Devil, for she had met him one dark Night in St. Pulchre's Church-Yard; Then the Monster call'd a Coach, methought with the Voice of a Christian; but a Sailor that came by said he might be a Crocodile for all that, for Crocodiles could cry like Children, and was for killing him outright, for they were good to eat in Egypt; but the Constable cry'd, Take him alive, for what if he be an Egyptian, he is still the King's Subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Prue.
SP.P:
Then he was hurry'd away by the Mob. A Bull-dog ran away with Six Joints of his Tail, and the Claw of his near Foot before: At last by good Fortune, to save his Life, he fell in with the Hockley in the Hole Bull
and Bear; the Master claim'd him for his Mon∣ster, and so he is now attended by a vast Mob, very solemnly marching to Hockley in the Hole, with the Bear in his Front, the Bull in his Rear, and a Monkey upon each Shoulder.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Mr. Mummy, you had best draw the Curtains of your Chair, or the Mob's Respect for the Dead will scarce protect you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: My Concern for him obliges me to go see that he gets off safe, lest any further Mis∣chief befall the Persons of our Masque.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Sweetly, Horace. Nunquam satis, and so forth. A Man can never be too cautious. Madam, sit down by me. Pray how long is it since you and I have been married?

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Near Three Hours, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: And what Anxieties has this Time produc'd! The dangers of Divorce! Calumni∣atory Letters! lewd Fellows introduced by my Niece! groundless Jealousies on both Sides! even thy Virginity put to the Touchstone! but this last Danger I plung'd thee in my self; to leave thee in the Room with Two such robust young Fellows.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Ay, with Two young Fellows! but, my Dear, I know you did it ignorantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: This is the first blest Minute of Repose that I have enjoy'd in Matrimony. Dost thou know the Reason, my Dear, why I have chosen thee of all Womankind?

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: My Face perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: My Wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: My Virtue and good Humour?

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: No. But for the natural Conformity of our Constitutions. Because thou art hot and moist in the Third Degree, and I my self cold and dry in the First.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: And so Nature has coupled us like the Elements.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Thou hast nothing to do but to submit thy Constitution to my Regimen.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: You shall find me obedient in all Things.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: It is strange, yet certain, that the Intel∣lects of the Infant depend upon the Suppers of the Parents. Diet must be prescrib'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: So the Wit of one's Posterity is de∣termin'd by the Choice of one's Cook.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Right. You may observe how French Cooks, with their high Ragousts, have conta∣minated our plain English Understandings. Our Supper to Night is extracted from the best Au∣thors. How delightful is this Minute of Tran∣quility! my Soul is at Ease. How happy shalt thou make me! thou shalt bring me the finest Boy!

DIV2.P:
No Mortal shall enter these Doors this Day. [Knocking again.] Oh, it must be the News of poor Lady Hippokekoana's Death, Poor Woman!
such is the Condition of Life, some die, and some are Born, and I shall now make some Repa∣ration for the Mortality of my Patients by the Fecundity of my Wife. My Dear, thou shalt bring me the finest Boy!

SP.SPEAKER: Footman.
SP.P: Sir, here's a Seaman from Deptford, must needs speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Let him come in. One of my Retale Indian Merchants, I suppose, that always brings me some odd Thing.

DIV2.P: What hast thou brought me, Friend, a young Drill?

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Look ye d'ye see, Master, you know best whether a Monkey begot him.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: A meer Human Child!

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Thy Carelesness, Sarsnet, has expos'd me, I am lost and ruin'd. O Heav'n! Heav'n? No Impudence assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Is the Child monstrous? Or dost thou bring him here to take Physick?

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: I care not what he takes; so you take him.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: What does the Fellow mean;

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Fellow me no Fellows. My Name is Jack Capstone of Deptford; and are not you the Man that has the Raree-Show of Oyster-shells and Pebble-stones?

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: What if I am?

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Why, then my Invoice is right, I must leave my Cargo here.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Miserable Woman that I am! how shall I support this Sight! thy Bastard brought into thy Family as soon as thy Bride!

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Patience, Patience, I beseech you. In∣deed I have no Posterity.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: You lascivious Brute you.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Passion is but the tempestuous Cloud that obscures Reason; be calm and I'll convince you. Friend, how come you to bring the Infant hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: My Wife, poor Woman, could give him Suck no longer, for she died Yesterday Morning. There's a long Account, Master. It was hard to trace him to the Fountain-Head, I steer'd my Course from Lane to Lane, I spoke to Twenty Old Women, and at last was directed to a Ribbon-Shop in Covent-Garden, and they sent me hither, and so take the Bantling and pay me his Clear∣ings.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: I shall find Law for you, Sirrah. Call my Neighbour Possum, he is a Justice of Peace, as well as a Physician.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Call the Man back. If you have com∣mitted one Folly, don't expose your self by a Second.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P:
The Gentlewoman says well. Come, Master, we all know that there is no Boarding a pretty Wench, without Charges one way or
other; you are a Doctor, Master, and have no Surgeons Bills to pay; and so can the better afford it.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Rather than you should bring a Scandal on your Character, I will submit to be a kind Mother-in-Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Mr. Justice Possum, for now I must so call you, not Brother Possum; here is a troublesome Fellow with a Child, which he would leave in my House.

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: Another Man's Child? He cannot in Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: It seemeth to me to be a Child unlawfully begotten.

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: A Bastard! who does he lay it to?

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: To our Family.

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: Your Family, quatenus a Family, being a Body Collective cannot get a Bastard. Is this Child a Bastard, honest Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: I was neither by when his Mother was Stow'd, nor when she was Unladen; Whether he belong to a fair Trader, or be Run Goods, I cannot tell: In short, here I was sent, and here I will leave him.

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: Dost thou know his Mother, Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: I am no Midwife, Master; I did not see him Born.

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: You had best put up this Matter, Doctor. A Man of your Years, when he has been wan∣ton, cannot be too cautious.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: This is all from the Purpose. I was married this Morning at Seven; let any Man in the least acquainted with the Powers of Nature, judge whether that Human Creature could be conceived and brought to Maturity in one Fore∣noon.

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: This is but Talk, Dr. Fossile. It is well for you, though I say it, that you have fallen into the Hands of a Person, who has study'd the Civil and Canon-Law in the Point of Bastardy. The Child is either yours or not yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: My Child, Mr. Justice!

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: Look ye, Dr. Fossile, you confound Fili∣ation with Legitimation. Lawyers are of Opi∣nion, that Filiation is necessary to Legitimation, but not è contra.

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: I would not starve any of my own Spe∣cies, get the Infant some Water-Pap. But Mr. Justice—

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: The Proofs, I say, Doctor, of Filiation are Five. Nomination enunciatively pronounc'd, strong Presumptions, and circumstantial Proofs—

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: What is all this to me? I tell you, I know nothing of the Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: Signs of Paternal Piety, Similitude of Features, and Commerce with the Mother. And first of the first, Nomination. Has the Doctor ever been heard to call the Infant, Son?

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: He has call'd him Child, since he came into this Room. You have indeed, Mr. Fossile.

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: Bring hither the Doctor's great Bible.—Let us examine in the Blank Leaf whether he be enroll'd among the rest of his Children.

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: I tell you, I never had any Children. I shall grow distracted, I shall—

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: But did you give any Orders against regi∣string the Child by the Name of Fossile?

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: How was it possible!

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: Set down that, Clark. He did not prohi∣bit the Registring the Child in his own Name. We our selves have observed one Sign of Fatherly Tenderness; Clark, set down the Water-Pap he order'd just now. Come we now—

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: What a Jargon is this!

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: Come we now, I say, to that which the Lawyers call magnum naturae Argumentum, Simi∣litude of Features. Bring hither the Child, Friend; Dr. Fossile, look upon me. The un∣equal Circle of the Infant's Face, somewhat re∣sembles the Inequality of the Circumference of your Countenance; He has also the Vituline or Calf-like Concavity of the Profile of your Vi∣sage.

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: Pish.

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: And he is somewhat Beetle-brow'd, and his Nose will rise with time to an equal Promi∣nence with the Doctor's.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: Indeed he has somewhat of your Nose, Mr. Fossile.

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: Ridiculous!

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: The Child is comely.

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: Consider the large Aperture of his Mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Nay, the Tokens are plain enough. I have the Fellow of him at home; but my Wife told me Two Days ago, that this with the Wall-Eye, and Splay-Foot belong'd to you, Sir.

DIV2.STAGE: [Prue runs a-cross the Stage with a Letter, which Fossile snatches from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: Whither are you going so fast, Hussy? I will examine every thing within these Walls. [Ex. Prue.] [Reads. For Richard Plotwell, Es{que} This Letter unravels the whole Affair: As she is an unfortunate Relation of mine, I must beg you would act with Discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: Reads. Sir, the Child which you father'd is return'd back upon my Hands. Your Drury-Lane Friends have treated me with such Rudeness, that they told me in plain Terms I should be Damn'd. How unfortunate soever my Offspring is, I hope you at least will defend the Reputation of the unhappy Phaebe Clinket.

DIV2.P: —As you say, Doctor, the Case is but too plain; every Circumstance hits.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: 'Tis very uncivil, Sir, to break open one's Letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: Would I had not; and that the Contents of it had been a Secret to me and all Mankind for ever. Wretched Creature, to what a miserable Condition has thy Poetry reduced Thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: I am not in the least mortified with the Accident. I know it has happen'd to many of the most famous Daughters of Apollo; and to my self several times.

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: I am Thunderstruck at her Impudence! Several Times?

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: I have had one return'd upon my Hands every Winter for these Five Years past. I may, perhaps, be excell'd by others in Judgment and Correctness of Manners, but for Fertility and Readiness of Conception, I will yield to no∣body.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Bless me, whence had she this luxuriant Constitution!

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: Patience, Sir. Perhaps the Lady may be Married.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: 'Tis infamous, Mr. Fossile, to keep her in your House; yet though you turn her out of Doors, use her with some Humanity; I will take care of the Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: I can find no Denoüement of all this Conversation. Where is the Crime, I pray, of writing a Tragedy? I sent it to Drury-Lane House to be Acted; and here it is return'd by the wrong Goust of the Actors.

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: This Incident has somewhat embarassed us. But what mean you here, Madam, by this Expression? Your Offspring.

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P: My Tragedy, the Offspring of my Brain. One of His Majesty's Justices of Peace, and not understand the use of the Metaphor!

SP.SPEAKER: Pos.
SP.P: Doctor, you have used much Artifice, and many Demurrers; but the Child must lye at your Door at last. Friend, speak plain what thou knowest of this Matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fos.
SP.P: Let me relate my Story. This Morning, I married this Lady, and brought her from her Lodgings, at Mrs. Chambers's, in King-Street, Co∣vent-Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Mrs. Chambers! To that Place I was directed, where liv'd the Maid that put the Bant∣ling out to be Nurs'd by my Wife for her Lady; and who she was, 'tis none of our Business to enquire.

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: Dost thou know the Name of this Maid?

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Let me consider—Lutestring.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Sarsnet, thou meanest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: Sarsnet, that's right.

SP.SPEAKER: Town.
SP.P: I'll turn her out of my House this Mo∣ment. Filthy Creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: The Evidence is plain. You have Coha∣bitation with the Mother, Doctor, Currat Lex. And you must keep the Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Your Decree is unjust, Sir, and I'll seek my Remedy at Law. As I never was espoused, I never had Carnal Knowledge of any Woman; and my Wife, Mrs. Susanna Townley, is a pure Virgin at this Hour for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: Susanna Townley! Susanna Townley! Look how runs the Warrant you drew up this Morning.

DIV2.P: Madam, a Word in private with you. [Whis∣pers her.] Doctor, my Lord Chief Justice has some Business with this Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: My Lord Chief Justice Business with my Wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: To be plain with you, Doctor Fossile, you have for these three Hours entertain'd ano∣ther Man's Wife. Her Husband, Lieutenant Ben∣gall, is just return'd from the Indies, and this Morning took out a Warrant from me for an Elope∣ment; it will be more for your Credit to part with her privately, than suffer her publickly to be carry'd off by a Tipstaff.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: Surprizing have been the Events of this Day; but this, the strangest of all, settles my fu∣ture Repose. Let her go—I have not disho∣noured the Bed of Lieutenant Bengall—Hark ye Friend! Do you follow her with that Badge of her Infamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Poss.
SP.P: By your Favour, Doctor, I never reverse my Judgment. The Child is yours: For it can∣not belong to a Man who has been three Years absent in the East-Indies. Leave the Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Sail.
SP.P: I find you are out of Humour, Master. So I'll call to-morrow for his Clearings.

DIV2.STAGE: [Sailor lays down the Child, and Exit with Possum, Clark, and Townley.]

SP.SPEAKER: Clink.
SP.P:
Uncle, by this Day's Adventure, every one has got something. Lieutenant Bengall has
got his Wife again. You a fine Child; and I a Plot for a Comedy; and I'll this Moment set about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Foss.
SP.P: What must be, must be. [Takes up the Child.] Fossile thou didst want Posterity: Here be∣hold thou hast it. A Wife thou didst not want; Thou hast none. But thou art caressing a Child that is not thy own. What then? A Thousand, and a Thousand Husbands are doing the same Thing this very Instant; and the Knowledge of Truth is desirable, and makes thy Case the better. What signifies whether a Man beget his Child or not? How ridiculous is the Act it self, said the great Emperor Antoninus! I now look upon my self as a Roman Citizen; It is better that the Father should adopt the Child, than that the Wife should adopt the Father.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.L: THE ancient Epilogue, as Criticks write,
Was, clap your Hands, excuse us, and good-night.
The modern always was a kind Essay
To reconcile the Audience to the Play:
More polish'd we; of late have learnt to fly
At Parties, Treaties, Nations, Ministry.
Our Author more genteelly leaves these Brawls
To Coffee-houses, and to Coblers Stalls.
His very Monsters are of sweet Condition;
None but the Crocodile's a Politician;
He reaps the Blessings of his double Nature,
And, Trimmer like, can live on Land or Water:
Yet this same Monster should be kindly treated,
He lik'd a Lady's Flesh—but not to eat it.
As for my other Spark, my fav'rite Mummy,
His Feats were such, smart Youths! as might become ye;
Dead as he seem'd, he had sure Signs of Life;
His Hieroglyphicks pleas'd the Doctor's Wife.
Whom can our well-bred Poetess displease?
She writ like Quality—with wondrous ease:
All her Offence was harmless want of Wit;
Is that a Crime?—ye Powers, preserve the Pit!
My Doctor too, to give the Devil his due,
When ev'ry Creature did his Spouse pursue,
(Men sound and living, bury'd Flesh, dry'd Fish)
Was e'en as civil as a Wife could wish.
Yet he was somewhat saucy with his Vial;
What, put young Maids to that unnat'ral Trial!
So hard a Test! why, if you needs will make it,
Faith, let us marry first—and then we'll take it.
Who could be angry, though like Fossile teaz'd?
Consider, in three Hours, the Man was eas'd.
How many of you are for Life beguil'd,
And keep as well the Mother, as the Child!
None but a Tar could be so tender-hearted,
To claim a Wife that had been three Years parted;
Would you do this, my Friends?—believe me, never:
When modishly you part—you part for ever.
Join then your Voices, be the Play excus'd
For once, though no one living is abus'd;
To that bright Circle which commands our Duties,
To you superior Eighteen-penny Beauties,
To the lac'd Hat and Cockard of the Pit,
To All, in one Word, we our Cause submit,
Who think Good-breeding is a-kin to Wit.

DIV1.HEAD: BOOKS printed for BERNARD LINTOTT between the Temple-Gates in Fleetstreet.
DIV1.P: THE Clergyman and Gentleman's Recreation, shewing the Pleasure and Profit of the Art of Gardening, containing se∣veral new Experiments and curious Observations relating to Fruit-Trees: viz. I. Concerning preparing the Ground for planting and sowing. II. Of the Method of plantnig Fruit-Trees in your Gdens. III. Concerning the most agreeable Disposition of a Garden. IV. Of Nurseries. V. Of pruning the Vine, the Peach, and Nectorine, the Pear and the Figg. VI. Of Grafting and In∣oculating. VII. Concerning the proper Disposition of Trees a∣gainst a Wall, the best kinds of each, their Order and Time of ripening. VIII. Part II. The 1st. 2d. 3d. and 4th general Causes of Barrenness. IX. Concerning the great Use and admirable Qua∣lities of untry'd Earth. X. A new Method of building Walls with horizontal Shelter, &c. Illustrated with several Copper-plates. By John Lawrence, M. A. Rector of Yelvertoft in Northamptonshire. Price 2s.

Fresnoy's Art of Painting. A Poem. With Remarks. Tran∣slated by Mr. Dryden. And an original Preface, containing a Pa∣rallel betwixt Painting and Poetry. By Mr. Dryden. As also an account of the most eminent Painters, ancient and modern: much enlarged, by Richard Graham, Es{que} The second Edition. To which are prefix'd, Verses from Mr. Pope to Mr. Jervas, oc∣casion'd by this Edition. Price 5 s.
The Rape of the Lock, an Heroi-comical Poem, in five Canto's. By Mr. Pope. The fourth Edition. Price 1 s.
The Temple of Fame. A Vision. By Mr. Pope. The second Edition. Price 1 s.
The Whatd'yecall it, a Tragi-Comi-Pastoral Farce, as it is acted at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-lane. By Mr. Gay. The second Edition. Price 1 s.
Trivia; or the Art of walking the Streets of London. By Mr. Gay. The second Edition. Price 1 s.
The She Gallants; a Comedy. The Heroick Love; a Tra∣gedy. And the Jew of Venice; a Comedy. All written by the Right Honourable Lord Lansdown. Price 3 s. 6 d.

The Works of the late ingenious Mr. George Farquhar; con∣taining all his Letters, Poems, Essays and Comedies, published in his Life time; viz. Love and a Bottle; the Constant Cou∣ple;
a Trip to the Jubilee; Sir Harry Wildair; Inconstant, o the Way to win him; the Twin Rivals; the Recruiting Offi∣cer, and the Beaux Stratagem. The third Edition. Price 6 s.

Praelectiones Poeticae: In Schola Naturalis Philosophiae Oxon. Habitae. Authore Josepho Trapp, A. M. Coll. Wodh. Socio, & Praelectore publico Lecturae Poeticae; à viro insignissimo D. Henrico Birkhead, Coll. Omnium Animarum olim Socio in ce∣leberrima Universitate Oxoniensi nuper fundatae. Volumen pri∣mum. Price 3 s. 6 d.

The Art of Cookery, in Imitation of Horace's Art of Poetry; with some Letters to Dr. Lister and others, occasion'd principally by the Title of a Book published by the Doctor; being the Works of Apicius Celius, concerning the Soups and Sauces of the Antients: With an Extract of the greatest Curiosities contained in that Book. To which is added, Horace's Art of Poetry in Latin. By Dr. King. Price bound 2 s. 6 d.

The Art of Love, in Imitation of Ovid de Arte Amandi; with a Preface, containing a more particular Account of the Life of Ovid, than has been hitherto publish'd by the Latin, French, of English Authors. By Dr. King. Price bound 3 s. 6 d.
An humble and serious Representation of the present State of Trinity-College in Cambridge. In a Letter to a Noble Lord. Price 4 d.

Observations, Rules, and Orders collected out of divers Jour∣nals of the House of Commons, entred in the Reigns of Edward VI. Queen Mary, Queen Elizabeth, King James I. King Charles I▪ and II. Price 3 s. 6 d.

Useful Miscellanies: Containing, I. A Preface of the Publisher of the Tragi-Comedy of Joan of Hedington. II. The Tragi-Co∣medy of Joan of Hedington, in Imitation of Shakespear. III. Some Account of Horace's Behaviour during his Stay at Trinity-College in Cambridge. With an Ode to entreat his Departure thence together with a Copy of his Medal taken out of Trinity-College Buttery, by a Well-wisher to that Society. By Dr. King. Price 6 d.
